Award.AwardTitle: The Clinical Experience for Pre-Service Science Educators: An Exploratory Study of Their Collegial Networks and Opportunity-to-Learn Trajectories

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Clinical experience is one of the features of teacher preparation assumed to have a significant impact on novice educators. There is, however, only a thin research base about what makes such internships effective. This study, funded by the National Science Foundations' Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program, through Track 4--Research on the Preparation, Recruitment, and Retention of K-12 STEM Teachers, will examine the clinical experiences of pre-service secondary science teachers from three different preparation institutions. The research study will: (1) investigate how teacher candidates use "advice and information networks" during clinical preparation to develop knowledge about the work of teaching and to inform decisions about planning, instruction, and assessment; (2) investigate candidates' "opportunities to learn" over time in the classroom, documenting which aspects of teaching novices are given the opportunity to try out and with what frequency; (3) develop quantitative measures reflect the quality of "advice and information network" experiences and the "opportunity to learn" data sets. These will be used to predict novices' edTPA (Teacher Performance Assessment) scores on planning, instruction, and assessment. This study will reveal from whom pre-professionals seek help in the field, what they learn over time, and how it influences their work with young learners. This project will help inform the design of clinical experiences by identifying how networks of support might be structured and how cooperating teachers might provide productive feedback, as well as articulating a trajectory of experiences that may improve teacher candidates' opportunities to learn over time.

The clinical experiences of sixty pre-service secondary science teachers will be investigated in order to develop a more empirically-grounded representation of the learning opportunities of pre-service educators during their time in K-12 classrooms. The first component maps out how teacher candidates use "advice and information networks" (cooperating teachers, field supervisors, peers in the preparation program, other teachers in the clinical placement, methods instructors, members of on-line communities, etc.) during clinical preparation to develop knowledge about teaching and to inform decisions about planning, instruction, and assessment. The second component examines teacher candidates' "opportunities to learn" over time in the classroom. It will document which aspects of teaching novices are given chances to try out and with what frequency over time--these experiences may include observations of accomplished teaching, interacting with students in varied ways, co-planning with a cooperating teacher, and co-teaching. Data for each of the first two components of the study will become part of a case history for each participant, and will include interviews with the pre-service teachers, the contents of on-line surveys by these novices, interviews with methods instructors and interviews with field supervisors. Quantitative measures will be developed that reflect the quality of "advice and information network" experiences and the "opportunity to learn" data sets. These will be used to test whether these composite measures are significant predictors of the quality of teacher candidates' practices as derived from an instrument known as the edTPA. The edTPA includes documentation of candidates' planning tools, lessons, assessments, analysis of student work, and analytic reflections on a sequence of instructional episodes they designed and taught. If researchers and teacher educators can understand the patterns of help-seeking and opportunities to learn by novices that contribute substantively to their knowledge and practice, then it could be possible to engineer opportunities for them to interact regularly with others who influence their development as professionals. Improved clinical experiences will mean more competent beginning teachers who, even early in their career, are better situated to support students in learning about and participating in science.

This work is supported, in part, by the EHR Core Research (ECR) program. The ECR program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field. Investments are made in critical areas that are essential, broad and enduring: STEM learning and STEM learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Empirical findings: One factor that was strongly correlated with TCs’ (Teacher Candidates’) opportunities to learn was the instructional congruence of the host classroom, meaning how well-aligned conceptions of teaching and learning were between the TCs’ clinical teaching placements and their university coursework. High congruence placements were those in which  1) mentors made content relevant to students’ experiences or interests, learning and activity reflected “big ideas” in science, and lessons were connected across units; 2) sense-making discussions by students was built into small group and whole class conversations; 3) students used a variety of different scientific practices to construct knowledge; and 4) formative assessments were used regularly to provide feedback to students or modify instruction. 

Only 17% of all placements were considered high-congruence. Medium-congruence placements were 23% of the total, and low-congruence comprised the majority of placements at 60%. These perceptions by TCs are problematic, given that low-congruence means instruction is focused on vocabulary level learning, doing activities that are not necessarily related to authentic disciplinary work, lessons are not connected conceptually, and formative assessments are not regularly used to make adaptations in instruction.

Novices in high-congruence placements tended to begin the school year engaging in substantive co-teaching and observe-and-repeat opportunities with their mentors. This activity, on average, lasted about three months and then transitioned into more independent types of teaching and assessment where the novice would often take charge of one or more class sections to make modifications and teach entire lessons. In only 4 of 39 low-congruence cases did novices begin by co-teaching with their mentors. Novices in these placements most frequently began the school year by “chipping in” information during a lesson, or observing and repeating segments of lessons they had seen their mentors do. In seven cases, TCs had no teaching role at all until January or February.

Many mentors, regardless of their own practice, were frequently unsure about the kinds of opportunities that their novices should have at different times of the school year, and how they would provide feedback that might be seen as valuable by their teacher candidates. For a majority of participants, and especially those in low-congruence classrooms, meaningful debriefing of their attempts at instruction were rare. University assignments and the required edTPA lessons were the only times, over a period of months, where such opportunities occurred.

In another line of analysis about teacher candidates’ opportunities to learn about assessment, we have noted that TCs had minimal opportunities to design or make sense of assessments, especially formative assessments. They typically are asked to grade papers, rather than to analyze student artifacts to inform instruction.

Also in the current set of studies for this project, we documented the role of TCs’ agency in seeking out opportunities to learn about the face-to-face work of teaching across the span of their clinical placements. We found that only 28 of our 65 novices appeared to use agency on a regular basis to 1) access more opportunities to teach in ways they felt were productive for students, 2) advocate for more central roles in planning or assessment, 3) go out to different classrooms and observe other educators, 4) request more and different kinds of feedback from their mentor, and 5) go out of their way after or between classes to learn more about their students. As with the teaching opportunities described above, the nature of these agentive acts varied by classroom congruence. In high-congruence placements, novices were more likely to request to experiment with instructional strategies that were variants of what the mentor was using, to volunteer to plan lessons or units, and to find ways to get more feedback from students on the quality of their instruction. In lower-congruence settings, agentive acts included inserting small elements of reform instruction (brief sense-making discussions, exit slips) into the more traditional lessons.  

Resulting development of resources: We have developed a website — MentorTeachers.Org. This includes animated videos of different mentoring practices, suggested trajectories for giving increasing responsibilities over to the novice, tools for cooperating teachers to use when observing instruction, and protocols for providing feedback. We have also started a series of newsletters that contain information for mentors and TC in the “right amounts” and delivered at “the right times” during the clinical experience.

We are disseminating our work broadly enough to inform teacher education personnel who can use and adapt our resources to construct a vision of pre-service learning that is appropriate to their context. Ultimately, the findings of this project have allowed us to theorize how pre-service teachers learn under supportive conditions, and more practically help us engineer resources and programmatic experiences to optimize their potential as professional educators.
